children.subject: I don't have experience with declaring in this method, but the way you would do it is apply normally, and then if you are rejected, appeal the decision. The appeal is where the essay part is. More on appealing: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/major-declaration-appeal

history.content: Student's answer is correct. The declaration process was changes slightly last semester.

Hi, I took CS70 this semester and grades haven't come out yet, but ill probably fall short of my required grade and get a 3.23, so just below the gpa cutoff to declare CS. I spoke w an advisor earlier this semester who said that sometimes, depending on availability and a convincing essay, they may consider students who just missed out. I emailed cs-advising but I wasn't sure if the email was active during winter break, and the deadline for declaring is really soon so I thought Id try my hand and ask here: does anyone have any experience in declaring after missing the gpa cap? The declaration doesn't have any space for a statement, so how would I do that? Should I wait for next semester and speak with an advisor in person first, before giving it a shot? Im super passionate about CS and in each of my CS classes, I did well towards the latter half( MT2, final, later projects) but my lack of any exposure to CS before taking 61a meant that in each class i completely bombed the first month's worth of work before improving. Im super nervous and would appreciate any advice. Thanks.
history.subject: Any chances of submitting a statement of purpose to try declaring with a 3.23?
